{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's presentation of normocytic anemia with elevated reticulocyte count and decreased haptoglobin suggests hemolytic anemia. The negative Coombs test and normal osmotic fragility test rule out autoimmune hemolytic anemia and hereditary spherocytosis, respectively. The family history of a male relative requiring occasional blood transfusions suggests a possible X-linked disorder. Taken together, these findings suggest a diagnosis of pyruvate kinase deficiency, an X-linked disorder that is the second most common cause of enzyme-deficient hemolytic anemia after G6PD deficiency. Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme in the glycolytic pathway that catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, producing ATP. Its deficiency leads to a decrease in ATP production, causing instability of the red blood cell membrane and leading to hemolysis.
